dataIdInfo.idPurp: Number of jobs per square mile in San Francisco.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
Data was obtained from the Local Employment Dynamics (LED) Partnership of the US Census Bureau at the census block group level. The LED Partnership defines a job as a link between a worker and a firm at which the worker has been employed during the reference quarter and during the quarter prior to the reference quarter. The reference quarter is Quarter 2 (April-June) of the year of interest. This definition of "job" is sometimes called a "Beginning of Quarter" job because it is assumed that the worker was employed at that firm on the first day of the reference quarter.

Blocks were aggregated to census tracts and density was calculated by dividing the number of jobs in a census tract by the area in square miles.

Field Definitions

Tract2010: 2010 census tract ID numbers

Pop2010: Population based on the 2010 US Census

Area_smi: Area of the census tract in square miles

Jobs_cnt: Number of jobs

Jobs_psmi: Jobs per square mile

Source

US Census Bureau, 2009 Longitudinal Employerâ€“Household Dynamics (LEHD) Survey, http://lehd.did.census.gov/led/
dataIdInfo.idCredit: City/County of San Francisco Department of Public Health, Environmental Health, Program on Health Equity and Sustainability, http://www.sfphes.org

Consts.useLimit:
American Community Survey (ACS) is a sample survey that does not survey every household. The values presented are statistical estimates; the true value is likely to be within a range represented by margins of error. The 90% margins of error provided with this dataset were calculated by statisticians at the US Census Bureau. The margins of error (MOE) can be subtracted from and added to each value to obtain the range of values that could represent the true value.

Generally margins of error represent a narrower range where sample sizes are larger. Thus where possible we have provided data collected continuously over five years instead of one year. However the multi-year sampling time frame means that the data do not reflect conditions at any single point in time.

In some cases, the data for specific census tracts lack the statistical reliability to be presented (we use a coefficient of variation/relative standard error of >0.3). This usually results from the population of interest being too small, either because few people live in that geographic area or because few people fall into the category being analyzed (e.g. a very small number of people are unemployed, therefore estimates for unemployment are unreliable).

More information and background on ACS data can be found in the ACS compass handbooks: http://www.census.gov/acs/www/guidance_for_data_users/handbooks/.

SFDPH Disclaimer: This data is being provided as public information as defined under San Francisco and California public records laws. The San Francisco Department of Public Health (SFDPH, or the Department) cannot limit or restrict the use of this data or its interpretation by other parties in any way. Where the data is communicated, distributed, reproduced, mapped, or used in any other way, the user should acknowledge SFDPH as the source of the data, provide a reference to the original data source where also applicable, and note any caveats specified in the associated methodological documentation provided by the Department. However, users should not attribute their analysis or interpretation of this data to SFDPH. While the data has been collected and/or produced for the use of SFDPH, the Department cannot guarantee its accuracy or completeness. As all data is associated with methodological assumptions and limitations, the Department recommends that users review methodological documentation associated with the data prior to its analysis, interpretation, or communication.
